things heat radiation and so that is moving to space but of course that

about 240 watts coming in because I'm subtracting out the hundred that's being reflected and 240 leaving so this would
be a net flux of zero right so this would be no change in temperature with
time but you can think about then how you would get a change in temperature
and so what's going on currently is that humans are burning fossil fuels and so
they're adding carbon dioxide to the atmosphere and carbon dioxide interacts
with this long wave radiation coming from the surface of the planet much more so that interacts with shortwave
radiation coming from the Sun and so it introduces a perturbation where you're
initially as soon as you introduce carbon dioxide into the atmosphere you're making the atmosphere optically
thicker in terms of the infrared and you you are allowing less than to escape to space and so you've created

so it's it's helpful to see where the uncertainty and the warming comes from if we break down this Q net flux term
into two different terms and so what I've done here is I've broken it down into what's called a forcing in climate
science and then a feedback term and so the feedback term is generally described
by this lambda which is called the climate feedback parameter and so the
uncertainty in the future projections of warming doesn't really come from this
forcing so introducing co2 for example into the atmosphere if you double co2
from 304 280 parts per million to 560 parts per million we know what forcing
that introduces on the system pretty well that's within narrow bounds of uncertainty so it's about 3.7 watts per
meter squared is what that does but there's a lot more uncertainty when you think about what happens to the net flux
and it has to do with what feedbacks do so as soon as you start warming up the planet you're gonna change a bunch of
other things so you can melt ice which would change this flux you can change clouds which would change this flux and
this flux you can increase you can change water vapor which is going to change this flux so all these other
changes come in and introduce uncertainty in your warming rate because of this feedback term so to get a better
idea of that we can imagine a situation in equilibrium and then solve this for
the change in temperature and so basically what this says is that okay the change in temperature is related to
the forcing divided by this climate feedback parameter and so there's a
smallest certainty in general for the forcing at least going into the future with co2 and there's a large uncertainty
in this feedback parameter which represents what all these other fluxes in the system do when you initially hit
it with forcing and so that then bleeds into a large uncertainty in the
temperature and so there are a number of ways the climate scientists try to narrow
uncertainty in this climate feedback parameter so I'll just kind of mention
